posts.name: Kegan Cherry
posts.cooked:
Hello everyone,

I'm [name], a rookie programmer from Team 7312, and I'm here to talk about a challenge we're facing with our robot mechanisms. We've been encountering issues with our elevator, elbow, and wrist systems. Despite setting up our controls and using components like PID controllers and encoders, these mechanisms lose their position and begin to fall when no commands are running.

We know that our current setup uses brake mode to reduce motion, but it's insufficient to hold the mechanisms in place. The PID controllers function properly when actively engaged, but fail to maintain position when commands cease. We've also enabled safety features like soft limits and physical switches, yet they don't address the root cause of the falling issue.

We're looking for guidance on how to ensure these mechanisms stay in place when idle. Whether it involves reconfiguring our commands, adjusting controller settings, or addressing potential mechanical issues, we'd greatly appreciate any insights or suggestions.

Thank you for your support as we work to solve this problem.

posts.name: Eli Barnett
posts.cooked: The PID controllers work while actively running but may begin to degrade once they cease operation. Don’t stop the controllers, though.

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: Robot apartments! invisible suburbs! skeleton treasuries!

posts.name: Jeffrey Davis
posts.cooked: There are three common solutions to address the issue. One involves increasing the gear ratio to enhance braking torque, another suggests continuously applying power to resist gravity, and the third proposes using springs or surgical tubing to counteract gravity. Each option has trade-offs: raising the gear ratio may slow the mechanism but ensures reliability; applying power maintains speed but drains battery over time; using springs requires mechanical expertise, increases weight, and avoids battery drain or slowdown.

You’re going to need to supply current to the motors in order to prevent gravity from causing your mechanisms to fall. Brake mode doesn’t actively apply power to the motor to offset spinning; instead, it shorts the motor leads together, making it much harder to backdrive and causing it to stop quickly if it was previously powered. This explains why it works when the robot is disabled, as long as there’s still power. I recommend keeping the controllers running within the subsystem so you can calculate the needed current periodically, every frame. Here’s an example:

[Link to GitHub repository]

Keep your control loops running as said. It can be as simple as your default command being holding position at a set point. Then any time you need to move that joint, you just have to change the set point.

posts.name: AllenGregoryIV
Kegan Cherry
posts.cooked: This is what we ended up choosing. Initially, I faced issues with loop overruns due to using the built-in WPILib PID class on the rio during each scheduler run. Eventually, I resolved this by transferring the PID functionality to the TalonFX via setting the motor control mode to positionVoltage.

posts.name: Mete Karadeniz
posts.cooked: How did you calculate the elevator G constant to hold the elevator?

posts.name: Tim Winters
posts.cooked: Calculate the smallest voltage required for the motor to move in both directions by applying a small voltage while running the motor forward and reversing the direction, then solving for \(k_G\) and \(k_S\) using the equations \(v_+ = k_G + k_S\) and \(v_- = k_G - k_S\).

posts.name: paulonis
posts.cooked: Turn off any feedforward by setting constants to zero or commenting them out. Run the elevator using feedback control alone and move it to a desired position that isn’t at a physical stop. Allow it to stabilize at that position and record the voltage the feedback controller applies to maintain it stationary against gravity. This voltage represents your kG value. Depending on the form of your feedforward equation, kG might also include terms like kS. However, for my approach to position control, I find it sufficient to ignore kS and set it to zero.

posts.name: Eli Barnett
posts.cooked: My personal approach is not to worry about kS for position control and leave it at 0. However, as long as you have sufficient motor power, this is okay. It’s usually worth doing the full routine to see how much of a difference it’d make; if kS is only a few tenths of a volt, then you can probably omit it.
